Generation I.Red: Its newly grown legs prevent it from running. It appears to prefer swimming than trying to stand.
Generation I.Green: (This entry was originally untranslated in English until it was reused in Pokémon FireRed .)
Generation I.Blue: Its newly grown legs prevent it from running. It appears to prefer swimming than trying to stand.
Generation I.Yellow: The direction of the spiral on the belly differs by area. It is more adept at swimming than walking.
Generation I.Stadium: The spiral on its belly is its internal organs seen through its thin skin. It is better at swimming than walking.

Generation II.Gold: Because it is inept at walking on its newly grown legs, it always swims around in water.
Generation II.Silver: The direction of its belly spiral differs by area. The equator is thought to have an effect on this.
Generation II.Crystal: The swirl on its belly is its insides showing through the skin. It looks clearer after it eats.
Generation II.Stadium 2: Because it is inept at walking on its newly grown legs, it always swims around in water. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) The direction of its belly spiral differs by area. The equator is thought to have an effect on this. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: Poliwag has a very thin skin. It is possible to see the Pok é mon 's spiral innards right through the skin. Despite its thinness, however, the skin is also very flexible. Even sharp fangs bounce right off it.
Generation III.Sapphire: Poliwag has a very thin skin. It is possible to see the Pok é mon 's spiral innards right through the skin. Despite its thinness, however, the skin is also very flexible. Even sharp fangs bounce right off it.
Generation III.Emerald: It is possible to see this Pok é mon 's spiral innards right through its thin skin. However, the skin is also very flexible. Even sharp fangs bounce right off it.
Generation III.FireRed: Its slick black skin is thin and damp. A part of its internal organs can be seen through the skin as a spiral pattern.
Generation III.LeafGreen: Its newly grown legs prevent it from walking well. It appears to prefer swimming over walking.

Generation IV.Diamond: Its skin is so thin, its internal organs are visible. It has trouble walking on its newly grown feet.
Generation IV.Pearl: Its skin is so thin, its internal organs are visible. It has trouble walking on its newly grown feet.
Generation IV.Platinum: Its skin is so thin, its internal organs are visible. It has trouble walking on its newly grown feet.
Generation IV.HeartGold: Because it is inept at walking on its newly grown legs, it always swims around in water.
Generation IV.SoulSilver: The direction of its belly spiral differs by area. The equator is thought to have an effect on this.

Generation V.Black: Its skin is so thin, its internal organs are visible. It has trouble walking on its newly grown feet.
Generation V.White: Its skin is so thin, its internal organs are visible. It has trouble walking on its newly grown feet.
Generation V.Black 2: Its skin is so thin, its internal organs are visible. It has trouble walking on its newly grown feet.
Generation V.White 2: Its skin is so thin, its internal organs are visible. It has trouble walking on its newly grown feet.

Generation VI.X: Its slick black skin is thin and damp. A part of its internal organs can be seen through the skin as a spiral pattern.
Generation VI.Y: The direction of the spiral on the belly differs by area. It is more adept at swimming than walking.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: Poliwag has a very thin skin. It is possible to see the Pokémon's spiral innards right through the skin. Despite its thinness, however, the skin is also very flexible. Even sharp fangs bounce right off it.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: Poliwag has a very thin skin. It is possible to see the Pokémon's spiral innards right through the skin. Despite its thinness, however, the skin is also very flexible. Even sharp fangs bounce right off it.

Generation VII.Sun: The swirl on its belly is its internal organs showing through. If the swirl is tinged white, that means it's affected by some disease.
Generation VII.Moon: It's still not very good at walking. Its Trainers should train this Pokémon to walk every day.
Generation VII.Ultra Sun: Despite the danger, it wants to come up on land. So it does its best to waddle along, but when an enemy finds it, it rushes back to the water.
Generation VII.Ultra Moon: The direction of the swirl on their stomachs differs depending on where they live. Poliwag aficionados can tell them apart at a glance.
Generation VII.Let's Go Pikachu: The direction of the spiral on the belly differs by area. It is more adept at swimming than walking.
Generation VII.Let's Go Eevee: The direction of the spiral on the belly differs by area. It is more adept at swimming than walking.

Generation VIII.Sword: For Poliwag, swimming is easier than walking. The swirl pattern on its belly is actually part of the Pokémon's innards showing through the skin.
Generation VIII.Shield: In rivers with fast-flowing water, this Pokémon will cling to a rock by using its thick lips, which act like a suction cup.
Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: Its skin is so thin, its internal organs are visible. It has trouble walking on its newly grown feet.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: Its skin is so thin, its internal organs are visible. It has trouble walking on its newly grown feet.

Generation IX.Scarlet: The swirl on its belly is its insides showing through the skin. It appears more clearly after Poliwag eats.
Generation IX.Violet: Its legs are newly grown, and it can't walk very well. It seems to prefer swimming through the water instead.
